text.text:
Nothing warms the heart, soul and belly like a hearty bowl of soup. So come in from the cold, slip off your gloves, and settle into an intimate moment with your food. 

From life-giving broths, spicy laksas, and creamy ramens to good old-fashioned Jewish penicillin, we've collated some of our favourite warmers. This lot will fill you up with warming goodness and maybe even cleanse your aura, daaarling.

tip.text: Koya is a surefire shout for hearty bowls of udon and sashimi complete with edible flowers. There's something so satisfying and oddly comforting about Japanese udon noodles. They're thick, chewy and fill your mouth with slurping sounds. Add the savoury broth and a couple of toppings and you're in for a treat. Choose between the broths, then add a couple of small plates like pickled plum or seaweed salad. Hearty portions and low prices make for very happy customers here.

text.text: Koya is a surefire shout for hearty bowls of Japanese goodness. There's something so satisfying about their udon noodles. They're thick, chewy, and fill your mouth with slurping sounds. Add the hot, savoury broth and a couple of toppings and you're in for a real treat - at a reasonable price too.

tip.text:
No prizes for guessing what spicy Malaysian soup is available at this Tottenham Court Road hotspot. Being from a Chinese family in Malaysia, chef Danny Tan cooks up all sorts of punchy street food flavours from various motherships - combining very traditional dishes with some of his own creations.

The menu is ha-uge with a selection of laksas (assam curry or coconut version), fried noodles, grilled meats, seafood and a whole section of vegan options. We got lost in the heady flavours of a very trad' Penang assam laksa - the rich fish broth is sweetened up with tamarind and soured up with lime, add shrimp paste, chilli, mackerel, pineapple and udon noodles and you've got yourself a winner. Sweet, sour and tangy in all the right quantities and much lighter than the coconutty laksa we're used to.

Decor-wise things are kept pretty simple, the ground floor is a more intimate affair while the basement is great for large groups, large drinks and gabbing away or simply staring blurry eyed into the open kitchen. Either way, in the words of Arnie (if he spoke as a collective), we'll be back.

text.text: No prizes for guessing what spicy Malaysian soup is available at this Tottenham Court Road hotspot. Get lost in the heady flavours of a very traditional Penang assam laksa. The rich fish broth of shrimp paste, chilli, mackerel, pineapple and udon is sweetened up with tamarind and soured up with lime - sweet, sour and tangy in all the right quantities and much lighter than the coconutty laksa we're used to.

tip.text:
Shoop Soup Shop, makes you wanna start penning a tongue twister about slop. Unfortunately for poets everywhere there's no slop to be seen here, just creamy and exotic Israeli inspired soups. Think beetroot soup with beef and semolina kibbeh (dumplings) or lamb fasolia (braised shoulder, white beans, fenugreek and hawaij spices).

If you're after a lighter lunch they've got your back with some zesty veg soups, salad boxes, sourdough toasties and even vegan desserts. Homemade tahini and chocolate truffles? Christ.

text.text: Shoop is a one-stop shop for all things soup. These guys doll out all manner of liquid love - inspired by flavours from around the globe. You've got your beef goulash; your black bean and jalapeño; your Iraqi white bean soup; your chicken broth and matzo balls; your Moroccan chickpea and lentil; your spicy cod with paprika dumplings; and, if you can believe it, even more.

tip.text:
Hot Pot is the kind of place you go if you fancy giving yourself a challenge. The concept of the restaurant revolves around the hot pot, naturally, which sits in the middle of the table and is full of differently flavoured broths including chicken, vegetarian and spicier numbers. You then choose from a huge list of fillings which includes an assortment of beef, chicken, lamb, pork, seafood, shellfish, vegetables and mushrooms with noodle and rice sides. This stuff arrives raw, to be cooked in the broth at your hands. You're in charge of this, so if you fuck it up it's really your fault.

There's a fairly calm feeling in the restaurant itself, with a gentle soundtrack and a strange kind of 70s porn set interior that seems to try and offset the stress of the cooking itself. The idea is that you sit there for a while with some pals and take your time with the hot pot, dipping in and out and making use of the unlimited sauces on offer. But if you're useless with chopsticks, you're in trouble.

text.text: Chinese hot pot meals provide not only delicious brothiness but also a little fun too. Dust off your finger skills for an evening of chopstick wielding at the cauldron. Choose your broth flavours and dip an assortment of beef, chicken, lamb, pork, seafood, shellfish, vegetables and noodles in the bubbling liquid. Just don't fuck it up, OK?

tip.text:
Housed in a residential Primrose Hill enclave perfect for celeb safari, L’Absinthe is a classic French Bistro characterized by red check tablecloths, local art on the walls and a “Bonjour!” welcome for all.

By day, it’s a cafe serving warm pastries (only an hour old we were promised), croque monsieurs and crepes to a crowd of local regulars but come evening, it becomes more ‘intimate bistro’, making it a nice place for a date. On the menu are all the classics and really this is what you should stick to - chicken liver parfait, thick onion soup (winter only), duck confit and steak frites are all winners. In true French style, vegetarians are not welcome.

text.text: There's something about a French onion soup that just gives us the feels. That first hit of melted cheese, crispy in parts, juicy in others; the soggy bread that soaks it all up and finally those savoury slurps below - we just luurve it. Get yours at this French bistro and make sure to tuck your napkin firmly in.

tip.text:
Having had a bit of success with their semi-permanent thing down at Maltby Street, the Jewish-soul maestros Monty's have found a permanent residing spot on Hoxton Street. They're serving up their famous homemade pastrami and salt beef bagels and sandwiches (they're one of the only places in the UK to make theirs from scratch) that have made them such a big hit.

These immense towers of flavoursome meats with accompanying sauerkraut, mustards and pickles, come in pretty steep at around the £15 mark when you add a side or two. But they make everything in house and it's a super tasty and filling bite so we'd say just about worth the outlay. They're also dishing out breakfast and dinner, along with a drinks list if you fancy having a few strong ones with your grub.

text.text: You've heard the rumours about Jewish penicillin - the chicken soup that cures colds, saves lives and probably will cure cancer one day. Well, Shoreditch fave Monty's Deli call theirs the Big Soup, and fill it with tender matzo balls, lokshen (noodles), roast chicken and carrots. The broth of the gods you might say.

tip.text:
Chef Masatoshi Ogata's signature ramen is a far cry from the 99p instant stuff you survived off at uni. Yielding inspiration from his travels across Japan working as a lorry driver, Ogata's 'perfect' Yamogoya ramen has now settled in Waterloo ends.

The menu consists of seven styles of hot and cold ramen, all made with their signature in-house broths, as well as their take on classic Japanese bites and dishes (think Hijiki seaweed, edamame and tofu salad, fried gyoza and crisptastic fried chicken). We were in need of healthy comfort so went for the Oyako chicken which hit the spot. And to finish, the sexiest looking dessert we've seen in a while: a raindrop cake served with a sticky sweet molasses syrup (kuromitsu) and roasted soybean flour (kinako). Hello Instagram...

text.text: Chef Masatoshi Ogata's signature ramen is a far cry from the 99p instant stuff you survived off at uni. Yielding inspiration from his travels across Japan working as a lorry driver, Ogata's 'perfect' Yamogoya recipe is creamy, savoury and packed with flavour. With five bowls the warm stuff to choose from you're sure to find your #ramenofdreams.

tip.text:
The terms 'cheap and cheerful' and 'no frills' spring to mind when pondering Wong Kei. The food is far from Insta friendly, the decor has a vague waiting room feel about it and you can't expect to be adding your waiter on Facebook at the end of the night (we tried). But if you trust your instinct, there's some genuinely good bites to try at some very reasonable prices.

The BBQ meats on rice won our vote, especially the pork belly which we slathered with chilli oil then happily polished off. The noodle soups are worth a mention too. Go for beef brisket, crispy pork or wonton - delicately parcelled bites in tasty broth, with noodles and spring onion. Some of them are off menu though, so think up what kind of soup you want and ask for it with conviction. We went for wontons and crispy pork - that's right, biatch.

text.text: The terms 'cheap and cheerful' and 'no frills' spring to mind when pondering Wong Kei. The food is far from Insta friendly, the decor has a vague waiting room feel, and the service is notorious. But if you trust your instinct, there's some genuinely good bites to try at some very reasonable prices. Go off menu for a bowl of wonton soup with added crispy pork and happiness will find you.

tip.text:
If you've ever enjoyed the bustling bistro vibes of 10 Cases, you'll be pumped for its baby sister, Parsons, just around the corner - this time focusing on seafood, but with all those same home cooking vibes we love. Walk through the French wooden doors, hang your coat (as is the proper way), and settle into lunch, rubbing shoulders and elbows with other fine folk.

Their menu is relatively small with an honest selection of bistro classics and some fancier bits. Get jiggy with the black rice with squid and cauliflower aioli - close your eyes and drink it all in, baby.

The wine list is, of course, mighty strong, with some bottles of stuff you'll never have heard of and some reliable Rieslings, perfect with your pissaladière - a bread-like tart from the South of France with caramelised onion, olives and anchovies, though Parsons make theirs with crab - fancy eh?

text.text: Walk through the lovely wooden doors of this French bistro, hang your coat (as is the proper way), and settle in for a delish' fishy lunch. With smoked bacon, potatoes and whatever shellfish they fancy, this creamy chowder number is right up our street. You may want to soak it up with bread, but we'd go for a portion of their infamous chips. Yes, dreams really do come true this time of year.
